item.title: Quick Notes - Coding Stata do-files with Sublime in Unix/Linux
item.description: I am used to writing code in notepad programs, such as N++ and the fantastic Sublime Text 3. Here's a quick note on connecting a powerful coding notepad in Linux to Stata.   Sublime, like many of these programming-oriented editing notepads, have massively powerful tools that crush Stata's default editor. Moreover, since many people are simultaneously juggling Python, R, and Stata (and more) scripts for a single project, the ability to work from one programming-oriented environment is nice.

item.title: An Investigative Journalist's Guide to Geolocating Media
item.description: Link: An Investigative Journalist's Guide to Geolocating Media bell?ngcat, a crowd-funded start-up of Middle East wonks, investigative journalists, and researchers, has made some waves for demonstrating how to geo-locate an Iraqi ISIS training camp. Here are a couple of fantastic guides to some of the techniques they use to geolocate media, combining picture/video data alongside common geographic tools. One of the interesting techniques used lately consists of extracting and mapping metadata from photographs using tools like Panoramio.

item.title: The Bastards Book of Regular Expressions by Dan Nguyen
item.description: The Bastards Book of Regular Expressions by Dan Nguyen I love regexes even more because they make it possible – if not trivial – to do research and analysis that is otherwise impossible, because believe it or not, most research and analysis start out with just giant blobs of text The Bastard’s Book of Regex is a great (free!) text on cleaning up crappy data with regular expressions.
